'{{transl|ar|DIN|Ê¾AbÅ« l-WalÄ«d Muá¸¥ammad bin Ê¾Aá¸¥mad bin RuÅ¡d}}' (), commonly known
as 'Ibn Rushd' () or by his Latinized name 'AverroÃ«s' (; April 14, 1126 â
December 10, 1198), was a Spanish Andalusian Muslim polymath, a master of
Aristotelian philosophy, Islamic philosophy, Islamic theology, Maliki law and
jurisprudence, logic, psychology, politics and Arabic music theory, and the
sciences of medicine, astronomy, geography, mathematics, physics and celestial
mechanics. Averroes was born in CÃ³rdoba, Al Andalus, present-day Spain, and died
in Marrakesh, present-day Morocco. He was interred in his family tomb at
CÃ³rdoba. The 13th-century philosophical movement based on Averroes'
work is called Averroism.

Averroes was a defender of Aristotelian philosophy against Ash'ari theologians
led by Al-Ghazali. Averroes' philosophy was considered controversial in Muslim
circles. Averroes had a greater impact
on Western European circles and he has been described as the "founding father of
secular thought in Western Europe". The detailed commentaries on Aristotle earned
Averroes the title "The Commentator" in Europe. Latin translations of Averroes'
work led the way to the popularization of Aristotle and were responsible for the
development of scholasticism in medieval Europe.
